author: @Andrumen01
text: Be careful with the intersection condition at y, you are only considering the top part, however, you do not consider cases of the bottom part. If you ignore the latter, you will have "ghost" collisions. Anyway, awesome tutorial!

author: @AkshayAradhya
text: You can actually simplify that long if condition to :  *if thingX<x+car_width and thingX+thingW>x:*   Explanation :  if the left edge of the box is less than the right edge of the car *AND* the right edge of the box is greater than the left edge of the car  *it is a crash*  :)

                       def crash():     message_display('You Crashed')      def game_loop():     x = (display_width * 0.45)     y = (display_height * 0.6)      x_change = 0      thing_startx = random.randrange(0, display_width)     thing_starty = -600     thing_speed = 7     thing_width = 100     thing_height = 100          gameExit = False      while not gameExit:          for event in pygame.event.get():             if event.type == pygame.QUIT:                 pygame.quit()                 quit()      if event.type == pygame.KEYDOWN:                    if event.key == pygame.K_LEFT:                     x_change = -5     elif event.key == pygame.K_RIGHT:                     x_change = 5     if event.type == pygame.KEYUP:                     if event == pygame.K_LEFT or event.key == pygame.K_RIGHT:                         x_change = 0                             x += x_change                              gameDisplay.fill(white)                    #(thingx, thingy, thingh, thingw, color)      things(thing_startx, thing_starty, thing_width, thing_height, black)     thing_starty += thing_speed     car(x,y)      if x > display_width - car_width or x < 0:             crash()     if thing_starty > display_height:             thing_starty = 0 - thing_height             thing_startx = random.randrange(0, display_width)                  if y < thing_starty+thing_height:             print('y crossover')      if x > thing_startx and x < thing_startx + thing_width or x + car_width > thing_startx and x + car_width < thing_startx + thing_width:             print('x crossover')             crash()                  pygame.display.update()     clock.tick(60)           game_loop() pygame.quit() quit()

author: @chrischristenson4294
text: Ok, here is the disclaimer:  I tried multiple solutions to the issue that I had, watched the video multiple times (too many to count honestly), and tried wild card ideas.  it was daylight when I established the issue and it is midnight now.  I figured out what the issue was and it turns out that the "if x > ...." needs to be in line with the print, not  indented from it.  As  a word of constructive criticism for sendex, "clean up your code and your video, please."  This isn't the first time that I have had a problem coding from your videos based on a simple mistake.  I don't know what editing software you are using but it could not be too hard to reshoot a section of your video if you mess up.  As far as your coding, it has too much spacing and leaves too much room for misinterpretation when reading.  Please don't take too much offense to my comment because I really support what you are doing with your channel, I am only saying that simple mistakes could be made from your videos that could have been prevented if you provided clarity or just out right replaced a section of your video.  Please take this into consideration and keep up the good work, this information would have taken me days or even weeks to figure out and you have reduced it to a short, but painful, segment of hours.

thing_startx and x + car_width < thing_startx + thing_width:                 print 'x cross over'                 crash()         pygame.display.update()         clock.tick(60)  game_loop() author: @violetbrina
text: Hey there! I tried a different way of considering collisions that works quite well. I create ranges for the x and y positions of the car and block and check to see if both the x and y overlap (I used 'block' instead of thing and _x instead of _startx). More lines of code, but you don't have to wrap your mind around cases!  #if the block and car collide they crash 		carXs = range( int(x), int(x + car_width) ) 		carYs = range( int(y), int(y + car_height) )  		blockXs = range( int(block_x), int(block_x + block_width) ) 		blockYs = range( int(block_y), int(block_y + block_height) )  		Xcollide = False 		Ycollide = False  		for carX in carXs:     for blockX in blockXs:         if carX == blockX:             Xcollide = True 		 		for carY in carYs:     for blockY in blockYs:         if carY == blockY:             Ycollide = True 		 		if Xcollide and Ycollide:     crash()
